subject: Re: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices"
msgSnippet: So said  Mike Clark  on  2002-11-23 ... arbitrary ... the ... level ... when ... Anthill ... I believe that building the tests needs to be performed by a
messageBody:
So said Mike Clark on 2002-11-23

>Craig Dickson wrote:
>
>>--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
>>wrote:
>>
>>
>>>You probably want something similar to
>>>CruiseControl. If you don't know
>>>about it, Google it, download it and try it. It's
>>>not quite what you
>>>want, but it can be used to build and test your
>>>product every 'n'
>>>minutes, and only if there has been CVS activity in
>>>the meantime.
>>
>>Actually I already use CruiseControl and you are
>>correct it is not quite what I had in mind.
>>
>>The scenario I am most interested in is a single
>>developer working on a small section of the code on
>>his/her own machine. They want to run tests regularly,
>>during development, but why should they run the whole
>>suite every time, when they are only changing a small
>>section. The time it takes to do a test run is one of
>>the major hurdles to getting developers to run the
>>tests in the first place.
>
>This is exactly why I prefer to manually build test suites at
arbitrary
>levels. I might have a DatabaseTestSuite that I run when working in
the
>persistence layer, or a StressTestSuite to run all the
>performance-related tests. I can pick a suite at the appropriate
level
>of granularity in the system and run it. There are certainly times
when
>I manually run all the unit tests in the system, and I also use
Anthill
>to do that automatically on a set schedule, but there are times when I

>want finer-grained control.

I believe that building the tests needs to be performed by a human,
because that's where the knowledge lies. If there were a nice graphical
tool to make it easy, would that help? Is it worth your while to build
it?
